FacilityStr1: Off FM127, 4miles SW of Mt Pleasant

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The following prevention program elements are common for both the Units 1 & 2 and Unit 3 Processes.  Management procedures that define responsibilities for review, update, action item resolution and control of Risk Management Program information are common to both processes.  Specifically, the following management procedures apply to both processes:

Management System; Employee Participation; Process Safety Information; Process Hazards Analysis; Operating Procedures; Training; Contractor Safety; Pre-Startup Safety Review; Mechanical Integrity; Hot Work Permits; Management of Change; Incident Investigation; Emergency Response Program; Compliance Audits

Detailed Maintenance Procedures and Operating Procedures were developed for each individual process.  The PHA for Unit 3 was performed on 02/12/2004 and Units 1&2 PHA on 02/12/2004.

The following prevention program elements are common for both the Units 1 & 2 and Unit 3 Processes.  Management procedures that define responsibilities for review, update, action item resolution and control of Risk Management Program information are common to both processes.  Specifically, the following management procedures apply to both processes:

Management System; Employee Participation; Process Safety Information; Process Hazards Analysis; Operating Procedures; Training; Contractor Safety; Pre-Startup Safety Review; Mechanical Integrity; Hot Work Permits; Management of Change; Incident Investigation; Emergency Response Program; Compliance Audits

Detailed Maintenance Procedures and Operating Procedures were developed for each individual process.  The PHA for Unit 3 was performed on 02/12/2004 and Units 1&2 PHA on 02/12/2004.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Monticello Steam Electric Station, Mt. Pleasant, TX 75455

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility.

TXU Power?s overall approach to accident prevention and risk management is as follows:

TXU Power (TXU) is committed to protecting its employees, the public, and the environment from any accidental 

releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities.  TXU has implemented safety, environmental protection, 

and risk management programs to minimize the risks presented by hazardous materials used at its facilities.  

If there is an accidental release, TXU will either provide, or request from others, immediate emergency response 

to minimize the effect of the release.  TXU will also immediately notify the public, through local emergency 

management agencies, of any actions necessary to ensure public protection.


Your facility and the regulated substances handled.


Monticello Steam Electric Station (MOSES) is an electric generating plant using fossil fuel (coal) as an energy 

source.  The coal is burned in large boilers to produce steam, which is used as the motive force for the TXU 

turbine generators.  TXU takes great care in reducing emissions from burning coal to the greatest extent 

possible by injecting an ammonia/air mixture into the pollution control devices (electrostatic precipitators and 

baghouses).  The ammonia reacts with sulfur dioxide present in the emission (flue gas) stream and acts to 

agglomerate the ash creating a larger particle size and improving performance of the pollution control devices.  


TXU uses anhydrous ammonia (CAS Number 7664-41-7) at MOSES.  It is purchased as a compressed liquefied 

gas in bulk from commercial suppliers and fed to vaporizers where the liquid is converted to a gas and then 

injected into the flue gas streams.  There are two separate ammonia systems at MOSES, each with an 18,000 

gallon storage tank.  Inventory is controlled to a maximum of

84,067 pounds of ammonia in each tank.  This 

inventory exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds established under the RMP regulations. 


The five-year accident history.


Within the past five years, TXU?s Monticello Steam Electric Station has not had any accidental releases that 

resulted in injuries or property damage.  Under the RMP regulations, all accidental releases of a regulated 

substance that "resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, 

injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage" within the past 5 years 

must be reported.  MOSES has an emergency response program that includes an emergency response plan 

addressing the EPA RMP-regulated ammonia system operated at the facility.  

MOSES' emergency response plan contains:

> Procedures for informing the local Emergency Response Agencies and the community about accidental 
   releases.

> Proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental exposures to ammonia gas.

> Specific procedures for emergency response to either stop the ammonia release and/or evacuate people who 
   could be affected by the release.

 
MOSES' Emergency Response Program includes the necessary emergency response equipment, personnel, 

and training to respond to potential releases.  MOSES has procedures for emergency equipment use, 

inspection, testing, and maintenance.  In addition, MOSES' emergency response plan has been coordinated 

with the Mt. Pleasant Fire Department.
 

Planned changes to improve safety.


TXU plans to continue the current Preventative Maintenance (PM) Program in an ongoing effort to improve 

safety and reduce the risk of accidental releases at MOSES.  The PM Program has proven effective in reducing 

potential risks identified during the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and demonstrates TXU?s desire to maintain 

the established Risk Management Program and provide inherently sa

fer processes.  The PM Program includes, 

but is not limited to, the following elements;

> Monthly preventative maintenance on equipment,

> Annual review and update of procedures, 

> Annual personnel training, and 

> Compliance audits and equipment inspections at a minimum interval of every three years.
Executive Summary





Monticello Steam Electric Station, Mt. Pleasant, TX 75455



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility.



TXU Power?s overall approach to accident prevention and risk management is as follows:



TXU Power (TXU) is committed to protecting its employees, the public, and the environment 



from any accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities.  TXU has 



implemented safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to minimize 



the risks presented by hazardous materials used at its facilities.  If there is an 



accidental release, TXU will either provide, or request from others, immediate emergency 



response to minimize the effect of the release.  TXU will also immediately notify the 



public, through local emergency management agencies, of any actions necessary to ensure 



public protection.





Your facility and the regulated substances handled.





Monticello Steam Electric Station (MOSES) is an electric generating plant using fossil 



fuel (coal) as an energy source.  The coal is burned in large boilers to produce steam, 



which is used as the motive force for the TXU turbine generators.  TXU takes great care 



in reducing emissions from burning coal to the greatest extent possible by injecting. 



an ammonia/air mixture into the pollution control devices (electrostatic precipitators 



and baghouses).  The ammonia reacts with sulfur dioxide present in the emission 



(flue gas) stream and acts to agglomerate the ash creating a larger particle size and 



improving performance of the pollution control devices.  





TXU uses anhydrous

ammonia (CAS Number 7664-41-7) at MOSES.  It is purchased as a 



compressed liquefied gas in bulk from commercial suppliers and fed to vaporizers where 



the liquid is converted to a gas and then injected into the flue gas streams.  There 



are two separate ammonia systems at MOSES, each with an 18,000 gallon storage tank.  



Inventory is controlled to a maximum of 84,067 pounds of ammonia in each tank.  



This inventory exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds established under the 



RMP regulations. 





The five-year accident history.





Within the past five years, TXU?s Monticello Steam Electric Station has not had any 



accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage.  Under the RMP 



regulations, all accidental releases of a regulated substance that "resulted in 



deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, 



injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage" 



within the past 5 years must be reported.  MOSES has an emergency response program 



that includes an emergency response plan addressing the EPA RMP-regulated ammonia 



system operated at the facility.  MOSES' emergency response plan contains:



> Procedures for informing the local Emergency Response Agencies and the community 

  about accidental releases.



> Proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental 

  exposures to ammonia gas.



> Specific procedures for emergency response to either stop the ammonia release 

  and/or evacuate people who could be affected by the release.

 

MOSES' Emergency Response Program includes the necessary emergency response equipment, 



personnel, and training to respond to potential releases.  MOSES has procedures for 



emergency equipment use, inspection, testing, and maintenance.  In addition, MOSES' 



emergency response plan has been coordinated with the Mt. Pleasant Fire Department.

 



Planned

changes to improve safety.





TXU plans to continue the current Preventative Maintenance (PM) Program in an ongoing 



effort to improve safety and reduce the risk of accidental releases at MOSES.  The PM 



Program has proven effective in reducing potential risks identified during the Process 



Hazard Analysis (PHA) and demonstrates TXU?s desire to maintain the established Risk 



Management Program and provide inherently safer processes.  The PM Program includes, 



but is not limited to, the following elements;



> Monthly preventative maintenance on equipment,



> Annual review and update of procedures, 



> Annual personnel training, and 



> Compliance audits and equipment inspections at a minimum interval of every three years.
